slides.heading: Choices
slides.text: You may have nicknames for your friends, but "peers" is probably not one of them. However, peers are people your age who share your interests. While you may not be familiar with the word "peers," you have probably heard of "peer pressure." That is when your peers try to convince you to do things they are doing.

slides.heading: Good and Bad
slides.text: Sometimes peer pressure can be a good thing. Maybe your buddies persuade you to try out for their basketball team or join their study group. Seeing friends set and achieve goals can inspire you to do something positive.

slides.text: Peer pressure can also be a bad thing. It can push you in the wrong direction or down the wrong path. Have you ever felt you had to prove yourself by doing something you knew was wrong? Sometimes peer pressure stops you from speaking up. You may worry about losing friends if you disagree with them. Peer pressure can also make you take dangerous risks. You may worry that your friends will make fun of you if you don't go along with the group, even if that could mean getting in trouble with parents, adults at school, or even the police.

slides.heading: What To Do?
slides.text:
What is the best thing to do if you find yourself in a tight spot? There are choices you can make if you feel pressured by your peers.

 

Before you say "yes" to questionable behavior, take a minute to think about it. This can help you avoid making a big mistake. To test your true feelings about a situation, notice how your body feels when you think about doing something. If you feel queasy when you think of saying "yes," pay attention. You are not being true to yourself when you go along with something you know is wrong.

slides.text: Saying "no" should be easy. The truth, however, is that actually doing so in a difficult situation can be tough. Plan ahead so that you have a reason to support your decision to say "no." You might say, "My dad said to be home right after school. Sorry, I'm out." Say "no," give your reason, and get moving. An exit plan, prepared ahead of time, is a good way to confront a challenging situation.

slides.heading: Strike A Deal
slides.text: Come up with a different idea. Suggest that you go to a movie or other safe place for fun instead of somewhere that may lead to trouble. Turn on the positive peer pressure, and rally your friends to do the right thing. If no one takes your suggestion, that is okay. Remember your exit plan, and use it to get yourself out of a potentially bad situation.

slides.heading: Slow Down
slides.text: If you do not know how to say "no," don't commit to the plan. Tell your friends that you are unsure if you can join them. Tell them you might catch up with them later. This gives you time to create an exit plan or figure out how best to say "no."

slides.heading: Tight Spot
slides.text: You may find yourself in a tight spot someday. Maybe you already have. Some of your peers may be making choices you know are wrong. Sometimes you may not know the right thing to do. Talk to an adult you trust about a difficult situation you are facing. A coach, a teacher, an older sibling, or a parent may help you decide the best way to handle it. They have probably faced peer pressure themselves. Spend time with people who share your interests and beliefs. True friends do not put you down when you stand up for yourself.
